Section 2.4 in the "Mathematics in Lean" book asks to prove the "aux theorem" for inequalities:
theorem aux : (a b c : \R) min a b + c â‰¤ min (a + c) (b + c) := by
Shouldn't there be an additional hypothesis stating that c >= 0?
In the real numbers that is true even if c < 0. Why do you want an extra hypothesis?
The theorem doesn't hold if a = 3, b = 5, c = -3
Nvm, I thought of min a b + c as min a (b+c)
